member.name: T:YAMP.Numerics.Eigenvalues
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix. If A is symmetric, then A = V * D * V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V.Multiply(D.Multiply(V.Transpose())) and V.Multiply(V.Transpose()) equals the identity matrix. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A * V = V * D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V * D * Inverse(V) depends upon V.cond().

member.name: T:YAMP.Numerics.LUDecomposition
member.summary:
LU Decomposition. For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the LU decomposition is an m-by-n unit lower triangular matrix L, an n-by-n upper triangular matrix U, and a permutation vector piv of length m so that A(piv,:) = L*U.
If m is smaller than n, then L is m-by-m and U is m-by-n.
The LU decompostion with pivoting always exists, even if the matrix is singular, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the LU decomposition is in the solution of square systems of simultaneous linear equations. This will fail if IsNonSingular() returns false.

member.summary: Array for internal storage of decomposition.

member.summary: Row and column dimensions, and pivot sign.

member.summary: Row and column dimensions, and pivot sign.

member.summary: Row and column dimensions, and pivot sign.

member.summary: Internal storage of pivot vector.

member.summary: LU Decomposition
member.returns: Structure to access L, U and piv.

member.summary: Is the matrix nonsingular?
member.returns: true if U, and hence A, is nonsingular.

member.name: T:YAMP.Numerics.QRDecomposition
member.summary: QR Decomposition. For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the QR decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal matrix Q and an n-by-n upper triangular matrix R so that A = Q * R. The QR decompostion always exists, even if the matrix does not have full rank, so the constructor will never fail. The primary use of the QR decomposition is in the least squares solution of nonsquare systems of simultaneous linear equations. This will fail if IsFullRank() returns false.

member.summary: Row and column dimensions.

member.returns: Structure to access R and the Householder vectors and compute Q.

member.summary: Creates the right QR decomposition (Givens or Householder) depending on the given matrix.

member.name: T:YAMP.Numerics.SingularValueDecomposition
member.summary: Singular Value Decomposition. For an m-by-n matrix A with m >= n, the singular value decomposition is an m-by-n orthogonal matrix U, an n-by-n diagonal matrix S, and an n-by-n orthogonal matrix V so that A = U*S*V'. The singular values, sigma[k] = S[k][k], are ordered so that sigma[0] >= sigma[1] >= ... >= sigma[n-1]. The singular value decompostion always exists, so the constructor will never fail. The matrix condition number and the effective numerical rank can be computed from this decomposition.
